title: ellipsoid bugs fixed

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-2.x_testing/334/
Can someone tell me what went wrong? How do I interpret the link offered by yt-fido?
content.html: Can someone tell me what went wrong? How do I interpret the link offered by yt-fido?

content.raw: It seems that your fork of yt is private.  The buildbot is unable to test your change because it can't pull it in.
content.html: It seems that your fork of yt is private. The buildbot is unable to test your change because it can't pull it in.

content.raw: Thanks, Nathan! Now I've changed it to be public. How could I make yt-fido to test it again?
content.html: Thanks, Nathan! Now I've changed it to be public. How could I make yt-fido to test it again?

content.raw:
There's a way to do it by forcing a test on the IRC channel. Unfortunately I didn't write that down when @xarthisius told me how to do it a couple weeks ago.

It's a bit ugly, but if you update this PR with another commit, the buildbot will try again.
content.html:
There's a way to do it by forcing a test on the IRC channel. Unfortunately I didn't write that down when Kacper Kowalik told me how to do it a couple weeks ago.

It's a bit ugly, but if you update this PR with another commit, the buildbot will try again.

content.raw: Thank you. I'll make another commit then.
content.html: Thank you. I'll make another commit then.

content.raw: @gsiisg would you mind taking a look at this?
content.html: gsiisg would you mind taking a look at this?

content.raw:
I worked with Pengfei on this PR and tried it on 3 separate haloes from my own dataset, none of the particles are outside of the ellipsoids now.

Approved.
content.html:
I worked with Pengfei on this PR and tried it on 3 separate haloes from my own dataset, none of the particles are outside of the ellipsoids now.

Approved.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-2.x_testing/335/
Are those errors because Pengfei didn't use the latest build of yt to issue the PR?
content.html: Are those errors because Pengfei didn't use the latest build of yt to issue the PR?

content.raw:
Here's the traceback for the error (both failures have similar tracebacks): http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4873/

If you don't see this error when running the unit tests locally it's possible that is the issue.  The buildbot merges PRs into the tip of the destination branch.  You should be able to get to the same state by doing the merge yourself on your local copy.
content.html:
Here's the traceback for the error (both failures have similar tracebacks): http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4873/

If you don't see this error when running the unit tests locally it's possible that is the issue. The buildbot merges PRs into the tip of the destination branch. You should be able to get to the same state by doing the merge yourself on your local copy.

content.raw:
ping @gsiisg @madcpf.

It looks like the issue is the changes for the way `e1 is manipulated near line 3601 of `data_containers.py`.  `np.dot` is not the same as `.sum(axis=1)`.
content.html:
ping gsiisg Pengfei Chen.

It looks like the issue is the changes for the way e1 is manipulated near line 3601 ofdata_containers.py.np.dotis not the same as.sum(axis=1)`.

content.raw:
Hi Nathan,

I've tested that np.dot gets the same result as .sum(axis=1). I'm confused about the mercurial operations. How could I find the tip of the destination branch? My repository is a fork of yt_analysis/yt.

Thanks.
content.html:
Hi Nathan,

I've tested that np.dot gets the same result as .sum(axis=1). I'm confused about the mercurial operations. How could I find the tip of the destination branch? My repository is a fork of yt_analysis/yt.

Thanks.

content.raw:
It will only be the same result if the dimensionality of e1 is as you're expecting.  This is not always the case.  In particular, it looks like the boolean objects are somehow using the ellipsoid object in a way that you're not expecting.

After making the following modification to your PR I'm able to get the tests to pass:


```
#!diff

diff -r 58cc7d2f9e33 yt/data_objects/data_containers.py
--- a/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py        Tue Jul 01 19:37:39 2014 -0500
+++ b/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py        Thu Jul 03 19:07:36 2014 -0700
@@ -3601,9 +3601,9 @@
         RX = get_rotation_matrix(-tilt, (1, 0, 0))
         RY = get_rotation_matrix(-t2,   (0, 1, 0))
         RZ = get_rotation_matrix(-t1,   (0, 0, 1))
-        e1 = np.dot(RX, (0,1,0))
-        e1 = np.dot(RY, e1)
-        e1 = np.dot(RZ, e1)
+        e1 = ((0, 1, 0) * RX).sum(axis=1)
+        e1 = (e1 * RY).sum(axis=1)
+        e1 = (e1 * RZ).sum(axis=1)
         e2 = np.cross(e0, e1)

         self._e1 = e1

```

You should be able to trigger the test failures on your local copy with the following invocation in the root of the yt repository:

    $ nosetests data_objects.tests.test_boolean_regions

No need to do any merging - your PR is a descendent of the current tip of the yt branch.
content.html:
It will only be the same result if the dimensionality of e1 is as you're expecting. This is not always the case. In particular, it looks like the boolean objects are somehow using the ellipsoid object in a way that you're not expecting.

After making the following modification to your PR I'm able to get the tests to pass:

diff -r 58cc7d2f9e33 yt/data_objects/data_containers.py
--- a/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py        Tue Jul 01 19:37:39 2014 -0500
+++ b/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py        Thu Jul 03 19:07:36 2014 -0700
@@ -3601,9 +3601,9 @@
         RX = get_rotation_matrix(-tilt, (1, 0, 0))
         RY = get_rotation_matrix(-t2,   (0, 1, 0))
         RZ = get_rotation_matrix(-t1,   (0, 0, 1))
-        e1 = np.dot(RX, (0,1,0))
-        e1 = np.dot(RY, e1)
-        e1 = np.dot(RZ, e1)
+        e1 = ((0, 1, 0) * RX).sum(axis=1)
+        e1 = (e1 * RY).sum(axis=1)
+        e1 = (e1 * RZ).sum(axis=1)
         e2 = np.cross(e0, e1)

         self._e1 = e1

You should be able to trigger the test failures on your local copy with the following invocation in the root of the yt repository:

$ nosetests data_objects.tests.test_boolean_regions

No need to do any merging - your PR is a descendent of the current tip of the yt branch.

content.raw:
Hi Nathan,

Thank you for your reply! The error is from test_boolean_regions.py, where pf.h.ellipsoid was used incorrectly. The last parameter should be a tilt angle(a number instead of an array).  

Thanks.
content.html:
Hi Nathan,

Thank you for your reply! The error is from test_boolean_regions.py, where pf.h.ellipsoid was used incorrectly. The last parameter should be a tilt angle(a number instead of an array).

Thanks.

content.raw: Sorry for assuming that test was doing the right thing - I guess the test had been silently doing the wrong thing this whole time.  Glad you were able to get the testing figured out.
content.html: Sorry for assuming that test was doing the right thing - I guess the test had been silently doing the wrong thing this whole time. Glad you were able to get the testing figured out.

description:
Bugs fixed:

- tilt angle was incorrectly calculated when the rotation matrices were changed last time.

- fixed the name of the unit vector notation used from starting at e0 instead of e1

Simplified Notation:

- consistent use of rotational matrices

- consistent use of dot products

- changed comments to reflect changes of some e1 to e0

To verify the modification, use this script:
http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4872/

It does:

(1) construct the smallest ellipsoid (with the center at the center of mass of the halo) that contains all the DM particles within the halo                                                  

(2) rotate the semi-principle axes of the ellipsoid to align with the x-y-z axis of coordinates                                                                                         

(3) plot particles positions on xy, xz, yz planes, 3 plots are generated.                                                 

Anticipated results:                                                                                                      

(1) on all 3 plots all the particles should be within the ellipsoid                                                       

(2) on the xy plot there should be at least two particles on the edge of the ellipsoid                                                                                                          

(3) on the xz plot there should be at least one particle on the edge                                                      

(4) on the yz plot there could be no particle on the edge
